results.content:
Some really good project examples, but as others have said the project structure is explained well, albeit at speed, but there is minimal React concept teaching (just starting project 2). Therefore certainly not a first course. As a guide the first project took < 18 mins of video to complete the big red countdown timer component.
As of writing to get the example working I needed to downgrade the babel runtime, with npm install --save-exact @babel/runtime@7.0.0-beta.55 for ui-material to work (or find an alternative).
results.content_html:
Some really good project examples, but as others have said the project structure is explained well, albeit at speed, but there is minimal React concept teaching (just starting project 2). Therefore certainly not a first course. As a guide the first project took < 18 mins of video to complete the big red countdown timer component.
As of writing to get the example working I needed to downgrade the babel runtime, with npm install --save-exact @babel/runtime@7.0.0-beta.55 for ui-material to work (or find an alternative).

results.content:
Initial Experience: It's clear this instructor has passion, and a desire to share. However if you're new to React and or you need to get a quick intro with  "real world" examples this is not your course. Don't take my word for it review the QA section to see the number of outstanding assistance requests and the length they have gone ignored (and its not just a seasonal window kind of scenario).

From the start you will note in the QA there are a mass of those like myself that have posted and waited for answers to real technical problems with the examples  the instructor offers. 

The code base is out of date and even after rolling back all my global and local dependencies to the exact versions sited in his examples, and going as far a s a complete fresh install, the code fails to function as described ( in most instances I have found what is provided via incremental code examples, works but upon compare I see some deviation and a savvy student should be able to debug and piece together a solution ).

I could go on but do your own due diligence and avoid this course until the content and examples are actually working as described.

Let's hope this is just my one off experience and will adjust accordingly if things change. Remember this is just my experience.
results.content_html:
Initial Experience: It's clear this instructor has passion, and a desire to share. However if you're new to React and or you need to get a quick intro with "real world" examples this is not your course. Don't take my word for it review the QA section to see the number of outstanding assistance requests and the length they have gone ignored (and its not just a seasonal window kind of scenario).

From the start you will note in the QA there are a mass of those like myself that have posted and waited for answers to real technical problems with the examples the instructor offers.

The code base is out of date and even after rolling back all my global and local dependencies to the exact versions sited in his examples, and going as far a s a complete fresh install, the code fails to function as described ( in most instances I have found what is provided via incremental code examples, works but upon compare I see some deviation and a savvy student should be able to debug and piece together a solution ).

I could go on but do your own due diligence and avoid this course until the content and examples are actually working as described.

Let's hope this is just my one off experience and will adjust accordingly if things change. Remember this is just my experience.

results.content:
I'm only into the section on the header js file, but I can see a problem with this instructors delivery.  Basically, he's not teaching.  He's saying "write this code," with little to no explanations. 

Here's some other issues.  While he explains how to install node (which I already had installed), he doesn't cover installing React.  He does have a file that tells you how to install some components that work with React, but he doesn't cover React installation at all. 

The IDE of choice is VisualStudio and I'm pretty tired of seeing instructors default to that.  In this case, his project setup lecture is absurd.  When he uses VS, he opens a terminal on the command line, does his create-react-app . command and magically it all appears in VS.  This wont work in the way he does it, for anyone else. For some stupid reason VS decides to HIDE all your files in the project.  You must go through some menu options to have them display. I mostly use IntelliJ/Webstorm.  But I thought I'd give VS a try.   I had nothing but problems, problems he doesn't cover (like getting the files to appear, or how to use git, with creating react files - as "create-react-app ." will error "files in directory conflict: .vs, etc."  UGH!

Basically if you HAVE to create a new project THROUGH VS.  VS can't load a directory of code like Webstorm/IntelliJ.  Then on the command line of this new project, if you do what he does "create-react-app ." it will fail if you allowed VS to create it's .vs folder or any .git implementation!!! He doesn't tell you that.   For me the react creation process will full out error on the VS project folder... so I had to create the react app into a named sub folder.  

** A "Watch Me Code" Class **
The instructor is talking rapidly and it's nearly impossible to keep up.  I have to sit and pause each section of code, because he uses his VS shortcuts to generate 20 lines of code... and moves on, all in the span of 10 seconds.  No explanation.

I had no experience with React, but I was happy to see it resembles a traditional OOP language, with classes, extends, etc.  But I'd imagine this might confuse an old school JavaScript guy who doesn't know these types of things - again no explanation.  

This is simply a "watch me build something" type of class that I'll most likely refund within my 30 days.

** Tips for the Instructor **
1. Show how to install the core material (i.e. React), it's easy yes, but if you take the time to show how to install node (equally easy), then do so with the object of the course.
2. Don't get VS centric.  Visual Studio might be great for you, but it isn't like any other IDE i've used.  If you're going to go exclusively into VS, then spend 3 or 4 lectures on its use. Otherwise stay generic using a standard IDE (atom, webstorm, intellij, etc.)
3. SLOW DOWN.  No one can type code and keep up with your pace.
4. EXPLAIN what is going on.  You say this is for people with NO React experience.  Said people may not know about Classes or Inheritance. So explain each step and what's going on.
results.content_html:
I'm only into the section on the header js file, but I can see a problem with this instructors delivery. Basically, he's not teaching. He's saying "write this code," with little to no explanations.

Here's some other issues. While he explains how to install node (which I already had installed), he doesn't cover installing React. He does have a file that tells you how to install some components that work with React, but he doesn't cover React installation at all.

The IDE of choice is VisualStudio and I'm pretty tired of seeing instructors default to that. In this case, his project setup lecture is absurd. When he uses VS, he opens a terminal on the command line, does his create-react-app . command and magically it all appears in VS. This wont work in the way he does it, for anyone else. For some stupid reason VS decides to HIDE all your files in the project. You must go through some menu options to have them display. I mostly use IntelliJ/Webstorm. But I thought I'd give VS a try. I had nothing but problems, problems he doesn't cover (like getting the files to appear, or how to use git, with creating react files - as "create-react-app ." will error "files in directory conflict: .vs, etc." UGH!

Basically if you HAVE to create a new project THROUGH VS. VS can't load a directory of code like Webstorm/IntelliJ. Then on the command line of this new project, if you do what he does "create-react-app ." it will fail if you allowed VS to create it's .vs folder or any .git implementation!!! He doesn't tell you that. For me the react creation process will full out error on the VS project folder... so I had to create the react app into a named sub folder.

** A "Watch Me Code" Class **
The instructor is talking rapidly and it's nearly impossible to keep up. I have to sit and pause each section of code, because he uses his VS shortcuts to generate 20 lines of code... and moves on, all in the span of 10 seconds. No explanation.

I had no experience with React, but I was happy to see it resembles a traditional OOP language, with classes, extends, etc. But I'd imagine this might confuse an old school JavaScript guy who doesn't know these types of things - again no explanation.

This is simply a "watch me build something" type of class that I'll most likely refund within my 30 days.

** Tips for the Instructor **
1. Show how to install the core material (i.e. React), it's easy yes, but if you take the time to show how to install node (equally easy), then do so with the object of the course.
2. Don't get VS centric. Visual Studio might be great for you, but it isn't like any other IDE i've used. If you're going to go exclusively into VS, then spend 3 or 4 lectures on its use. Otherwise stay generic using a standard IDE (atom, webstorm, intellij, etc.)
3. SLOW DOWN. No one can type code and keep up with your pace.
4. EXPLAIN what is going on. You say this is for people with NO React experience. Said people may not know about Classes or Inheritance. So explain each step and what's going on.

results.content: If you get it for $11, it's fine. You will learn a lot of animation and icon techniques (there are better and easier techniques out there), and you will definitely get basic React and Redux practice. If you are here for the e-commerce app though, you will not have an app ready for production or portfolio -- unless your potential employer isn't paying attention. Lots of bugs, routes that are not RESTful, variables named poorly, overcomplicated code, and worst of all, **zero** replies to any questions you might have. Still, if you already know best practices and you want what's listed in the first sentence, for $11 it's worth a buy.
results.content_html: If you get it for $11, it's fine. You will learn a lot of animation and icon techniques (there are better and easier techniques out there), and you will definitely get basic React and Redux practice. If you are here for the e-commerce app though, you will not have an app ready for production or portfolio -- unless your potential employer isn't paying attention. Lots of bugs, routes that are not RESTful, variables named poorly, overcomplicated code, and worst of all, **zero** replies to any questions you might have. Still, if you already know best practices and you want what's listed in the first sentence, for $11 it's worth a buy.

results.content:
Very good course so far. It has the merit to be different from all the other React courses I follow here on Udemy (and I am enrolled in a bunch of courses). It does not seem as popular as some other courses, but I am not afraid to say that what I learned so far feel more real-world, professional and useful for an upcoming freelancer or a junior developer. Projects in this course are more convincing and solid to display.
1 project uses Firebase and the other one uses the MERN stack.
I have a decent knowledge in React/Redux/Express/Node but this course offers many new stuff to learn (especially in term of UI design)

results.content: This was my 3rd course on React, so by the time I got to this one I was starting to grasp the concepts, but not everything had "clicked in place" for me yet. This course really  made all the dots connect for me, and I was able to go on to work on fairly complex applications as a developer in the "real world".  Building the 3 applications in the course really made it easy to connect the theory to the practical aspects of actually implementing meaningful projects.  Although questions do not get answered by the author of the course, I would highly recommend this course to anyone trying to learn React. Really nicely done!
results.content_html: This was my 3rd course on React, so by the time I got to this one I was starting to grasp the concepts, but not everything had "clicked in place" for me yet. This course really made all the dots connect for me, and I was able to go on to work on fairly complex applications as a developer in the "real world". Building the 3 applications in the course really made it easy to connect the theory to the practical aspects of actually implementing meaningful projects. Although questions do not get answered by the author of the course, I would highly recommend this course to anyone trying to learn React. Really nicely done!

results.content:
Fernando is very good at teaching concepts and helping you understand what is going on. He takes the time to explain everything.
However, I feel like some of the things that he does is over-engineered and could be done in a much simpler way. Sometimes the videos drag on for too long and you lose concentration. He also waffles about nothing at points. 
The first 2 projects were great and well structured, but when it got to the third, the content was great we built some really cool stuff with great features, but the folder structure and naming conventions are a bit all over the place. 
Overall I am very happy and would definitely recommend this course to anyone looking to advance their React & Node skills
results.content_html:
Fernando is very good at teaching concepts and helping you understand what is going on. He takes the time to explain everything.
However, I feel like some of the things that he does is over-engineered and could be done in a much simpler way. Sometimes the videos drag on for too long and you lose concentration. He also waffles about nothing at points.
The first 2 projects were great and well structured, but when it got to the third, the content was great we built some really cool stuff with great features, but the folder structure and naming conventions are a bit all over the place.
Overall I am very happy and would definitely recommend this course to anyone looking to advance their React & Node skills

results.content: Great course. This course is not for beginners but for intermediate React users since it doesn't really go into details with the basic stuff. There's lots of good techniques about reusable components and functions.

results.content:
Excellence.  Covering such large projects is daunting and maybe even hard to stick with over the duration of the course, but the fact is that you are getting experience bringing together a complete project which has great value.

The instructor has added so much to this course I almost feel bad for choosing this as my freebie on Black Friday. Well worth the money.

I've had so many take aways and real world applications of this material already, easily one the best Udemy experiences Ive had so far.

results.content:
The instructor explains the basics of React and E6 very clearly. I haven't gotten to the bigger practical projects yet, but I am very happy with the React for Web Mini-Course. It is not mini. It is very thorough. I am looking forward to the practical project section.

Update: I have started the Waves project which is project 3 and I am quite impressed and amazed at how thorough and straightforward  the instructor is at explaining the ins and outs of every aspect of full stack development, from setting up MongoDB, creating the server logic, setting up the models, explaining login and passwords, and on and on and on, on top of React fro the front end. I am very impressed. This is one of the best courses I have taken on Udemy.

results.content:
I took this course in 2020, The course is not up to date, there is no support at all for asked questions. there is some code that not working anymore (scope changed from the time that the course was created). project 2 is not finshed at all (there is bugs in the project, checked on the instructor project as well).
as I said - not up to date, no updates or answer questions, no support at all. There are much better react courses to buy on udemy.

results.content: Ok here we go,  what can I say, I love this course simply because it has exactly what I needed, what to make your own ecomerce site with react and the MERN stack? you got it, what to learn nodemailer, file uploader, password reset , send emails to those who have registered or reset the password , or emails to those who purchased from your site, animations real world projects , how to have a user and admin set up, css transitions how to use css transitions to save time from doing your own css animations, how to use 3rd party libraries to save you time, you have it all here, this course is for those who have been using react but needed to fill in the gaps because of other courses that do not cover the real world scenarios , Code Rev gets 5 stars from me, I have both his react courses and his Native react as well, keep up the good work!

results.content:
When I first saw those projects, I felt it is what I need. However, it is difficult to follow, he jumps back and forth between different files.
He knows what he needs to do, but I cannot. It is better to organize what needs to be done. For example, create state first then functions then pass it to components. He did the opposite way.
